7.text:
Down House in Kent was for forty years home
to Charles Darwin, one of the most influential

14.text: thinkers in the history of scientific discovery.

18.text:
It's here surrounded by his large family and
his wife Emma, that Darwin developed his groundbreaking

24.text: theory of evolution by natural selection.

40.text:
Arriving at the house you get a real sense
of Darwin the naturalist. The scientist. But

46.text:
also of Darwin as the family man. A visit
here is truly inspiring. You don't only feel

54.text:
the presence of that great scientist but also
it's bristling with a sense of fun through

60.text:
experimentation, something that would have
arisen because of that family life here.

69.text:
In Darwin's study, you can find many of his
books, artifacts and maps. The tools of his

75.text:
discoveries are spread out everywhere; specimen
jars, dissection tools a magnifying glass..

83.text:
There is the chair where Darwin sat and that's
the board that he rested upon when he was

91.text:
writing his famous book 'On the Origin of
Species' one of the most important books in

97.text:
our history. Sat in here in this space with
his quill scraping across the paper. This

103.text:
really is the inner sanctum of zoology. Standing
in here looking at all of his bits and pieces,

111.text:
all of his clutter which stimulated his curiosity,
his creativity. It's amazing!

118.text:
By startling contrast, elsewhere in the house
you'll find a surprising discovery. It's a

124.text:
make-shift stair slide that Charles and Emma
made for their children. If Darwin's letters

130.text:
are anything to go by, then the life that
his children led here was fairly riotous for

136.text:
"The children are growing so quite out of
all rule in the drawing room. Jumping on everything

141.text:
and butting like young bulls at every chair
and sofa that I am going to have the dining

147.text:
room fire lighted tomorrow and keep them out
of the drawing room."

151.text:
They had rope swings hung from these ceilings,
they would play cricket along here and throw

158.text:
lead darts at one another, protecting themselves
with wooden shields.

162.text:
Today fittingly, a visit to Down House is
a very hands-on experience. You can get an

170.text:
interactive multimedia tour narrated by David
Attenborough or play a variety if family games.

178.text:
You can also discover a replica of Darwin's
cabin from his voyage on HMS Beagle where

183.text:
he drew inspiration from many of his discoveries
and continued his life long passion for collecting

194.text:
Like all good naturalists, Darwin was a great
collector. He even collected a tortoise from

200.text:
the Galapagos which had grown two inches by
the time he got it back here to the UK. But

206.text:
looking around this study the one thing that
my eye was drawn to is the little wicker dog

212.text:
basket down there on the floor because it
was there that his trusty dog Polly slept

217.text:
waiting, perhaps just listening for the sound
of that quill going down, and then rushing

224.text:
across this carpet and jumping up and saying
"Charles, take me for a walk!"

231.text:
Outside, on the sand walk, Darwin rewarded
his dogs patience. Going for a walk every

238.text:
day. His kids would often join him playing
games or helping him with his observations.

243.text:
When I walk here today this place brings me
back to a world that was bursting with birds

250.text:
and butterflies the very things that were
stimulating Dawin's creativity and his curiosity.

257.text:
While for Darwin, the gardens were a place
to experiment, for the children they were

264.text:
a playground. Whether playing in clay pits,
or navigating the lawns on stilts, they made

272.text:
In 1863 Darwin constructed a heated greenhouse
here with the help of a local gardener.

281.text:
Annie I love it in here. The quality of the
light, that warm, moist smell of greenhouse

291.text:
is undoubtedly unchanged from Dawin's time.
It's fabulous isn't it.

299.text:
Well what we've got here is a range of tropical
Orchids, the type of which Darwin would have

303.text:
himself experimented on back in his day. The
gardeners here have tried to recreate the

309.text:
We've got one in flower there as well, look
at that, that is remarkably exotic isn't it,

313.text:
stunning. What about kids though, when they
come what do they get?

315.text:
Well there's always something nice and gory
at Down House for the youngsters. So over

319.text:
on this side we have a series of carnivorous
plants which used to eat various things including

325.text: He gave toenail clippings to Venus Fly Traps?

328.text:
Which I think was a bit mean, he could have
given them flies but kids love watching them

332.text: snap shut on those insects don't they?

334.text:
Absolutely, yes. Again, out here in the gardens
we've actually got a observation bee hive

338.text:
where you can see the bees working to create
their honeycomb structures between two panels

343.text:
of glass so it's absolutely amazing to see
these fantastic little creatures going about

348.text:
Kids love getting their nose into that sort
of stuff don't they?

351.text: I want them to leave here as young biologists!

354.text: That would be nice, wouldn't it?

358.text:
I wish I could tell Darwin all I know because
of him. All the inexplicables explained, all

366.text:
the wonders, the miracles, the brilliant things
that I have seen through eyes that he opened.

375.text:
I like to imagine that some young people might
visit Down House with no real idea who Darwin

381.text:
was. But when they come here, perhaps lead
by their parents or the staff of English Heritage

386.text:
they look at his collection and his life which
is brought to life in such an exciting and

391.text:
exhilarating and fun way that they will leave
thinking I've been in the place where a great

397.text:
man lived and thought, and came up with remarkable
ideas in an incredibly important time.

405.text:
I like to think that some of those young people
might leave thinking 'I would be a biologist

410.text:
too'. They might be stimulated by what they've
found here, because after all in the future

416.text:
we are going to need more Darwins to help
us look after all of this.
